awd_titl_txt: EID:   Collaborative Research: Invasion and Infection: Translocation and Transmission: An Experimental Study with Mycoplasma in Desert Tortoises
awd_abstract_narration:
Solar panel development in the Western Mojave has resulted in a large number of threatened Desert Tortoises being moved from one location to another. Studies have shown that this species has become threatened through habitat loss and pneumonia infections and the translocation of tortoises will exacerbate disease risk. This project will examine the effects of social network structure on disease transmission dynamics using desert tortoises as a model system. The project will use a non-fatal mycoplasm infection and controlled introductions to follow disease spread in a system where the movements and interactions of all individuals can be tracked. The investigators will examine when translocation disrupts contact patterns and increases likelihood of an outbreak. Specifically they will undertake detailed experiments at both small and large scales and link these with probabilistic network models. 

A fundamental part of this project is to identify a relationship between population structure, contact patterns and disease spread that can be used more generally to predict the likelihood of disease outbreaks. One outcome will be a management tool that can be used to assess risk of disease outbreaks in relation to tortoise translocation. More generally the researchers seek to examine the relationships between contact patterns and disease risk in other types of populations, including human and livestock. In this respect this study will be of great importance in understanding how emerging infections invade naïve populations.

por.por_cntn:
Wildlife translocation – the intentional movement of one or more individuals to a new location – can be a disturbance to the population, even if the relocation is intended to positively benefit the species. In the North American southwest, managers coordinate translocations of the desert tortoise when urban expansion, military training, or more recently, large-scale solar development, encroaches upon the species’ habitat. Relocated tortoises then face an unfamiliar landscape, which can result in altered behavior, population dynamics and interspecies processes, including how parasites living on or within each animal can move and transmit through the population. Our study combined epidemiological and social network theory and simulation with empirical data from studies of captive and wild tortoise populations to better understand how translocation-driven changes to the population may interact with inherent behavioral patterns and endemic disease dynamics.  We also examined broader themes in animal behavior, connectivity, and epidemiology across wildlife taxa, which led to data syntheses and the production of new tools for understanding animal connectivity patterns and disease dynamics in diverse host populations and communities.

Our initial investigations show that as translocated tortoises move across their new landscape, their space-use patterns create greater connectivity within the population receiving new members compared to nearby unaltered populations. Simulations indicated that this change in spatial connectivity could increase transmission rates, but this result would depend on how effectively a pathogen can transmit between hosts and whether tortoises are likely to interact when given the opportunity. After analyzing tortoise contact patterns through indirect and direct means, we found a number of internal and external factors (e.g., sex, season, local density, resource availability) influence how tortoises share habitat and interact with conspecifics, but generally, their contact patterns present low risk for rapid transmission through the population. Generally low contact rates may not, however, prevent long-term spread of the chronic pathogen present in tortoise populations. Our studies of the transmission of the bacterial pathogen Mycoplasma agassizii, and the chronic infections that resulted demonstrate how infection heterogeneity can be a critical element in determining pathogen spread through a population. Host infection load and infectiousness varied substantially though time and from individual to individual, with some hosts actively shedding pathogen for many years. The combination of hosts with acute and chronic shedding periods can allow local and distant pathogen spread despite low population connectivity. Our combined findings have led to a greater understanding of the complex endemic disease patterns in tortoises, which are the product of within host, between host, and between population interactions. The resulting publications and additional data provided to federal managers will allow more informed decisions and protocols that reduce the risk of disease outbreak during translocations. The field studies conducted over the years have also provided countless hands-on training opportunities to 32 conservation research interns from diverse backgrounds – many of whom have continued their development in ecology or wildlife science through graduate school programs. The study goals, methods and ecological findings were presented to middle school classrooms in collaboration with Clark County School District Programs that aimed to foster interest in STEM fields and to encourage continued education in inner city and underperforming school districts. 

In addition to these species-specific findings and outreach events, we spearheaded the creation of a suite of network-driven tools that can be applied to any host species, including a repository of published animal social network data from 47 different species.
